Address.Line1: Broad Institute of MIT and Harvard
Address.Line2: 415 Main Street, Cambridge, MA 02142 United States

HomePage.Title: If you or your family member has a rare and genetically undiagnosed condition, you may be eligible to join a patient-driven research study aimed at discovering the genes underlying your family’s rare disease.
HomePage.Text: The Rare Genomes Project (RGP) at the Broad Institute of MIT and Harvard is a patient-driven research study led by genomics experts and clinicians who believe that the latest advances in genomic sequencing are changing medicine and should be accessible to families with rare and undiagnosed conditions.

Discovery.Title: Aid Discovery
Discovery.Subtitle: More than half of the genes underlying rare diseases remain undiscovered.
Discovery.Text: By participating in the Rare Genomes Project, you can help researchers identify the genes that cause rare disease. If you are eligible for the study, we will use genomic sequencing to look for the cause of the rare, undiagnosed disease in your family.

Answers.Title: Find Answers
Answers.Subtitle: Your family’s diagnosis belongs to you.
Answers.Text: If we find a genetic change that may be the cause of the rare disease in your family, we will confirm it in a clinical lab and work with your local doctor to return the result to you.

Involved.Title: Get Involved
Involved.Subtitle: Join the research community.
Involved.Text: The Rare Genomes Project is supported by The Broad Institute of MIT and Harvard in partnership with patients and rare disease advocates. We believe that families should be at the center of research involving their diseases, and encourage the involvement of families and the advocacy groups that support them throughout the study.

Data.Title: Share Data
Data.Subtitle: Data sharing is crucial for improving diagnosis rates of rare disease worldwide.
Data.Text1: The genetic information generated in this project will be shared with other scientists to ensure it has the widest possible impact. Your genetic data can help other families and improve scientists’ understanding of rare disease. Learn more about our data sharing policies

One.Title: Tell us your story
One.Text3: to see a broad overview of the study and learn how you can start an application. The information will be reviewed by our study team, and eligible families will be invited to participate. We will arrange a time to have a detailed discussion about the study and send a consent form.

Two.Title: Submit a sample
Two.Text: Once enrolled, we will mail a pre-paid sample collection kit directly to you and your family. We will also ask you more about medical history and ask for copies of medical records, including any prior genetic test results.

Three.Title: Discover
Three.Text: Through DNA sequencing, we may discover the genetic cause of the rare disease in your family and will work with you and your doctor to return important results to you. We will also share de-identified data broadly with the scientific community to empower discoveries in rare disease research.

Quote.Text: "This research project really understands the importance of bringing patients in as partners and engaging patients in a novel way. It's critical to do that because patients are often the ones that start driving the research."
Quote.Author: -Matt Might, Caregiver and Director, Hugh Kaul Precision Medicine Institute

Partners.Title: Our advocacy partners
Partners.Rare: Rare science accelerating cures for rare kids

LastSection.Title: You can be the driving force behind rare disease research.
LastSection.Text: Many thanks to the National Institutes of Health (NIH), the Muscular Dystrophy Association (MDA), Illumina, Inc., Broad Institute, the Silicon Valley Community Foundation, and Shriners Hospitals for Children for their financial support of our project.

AboutUsPage.Title: About Us

Intro.Paragraph: The Rare Genomes Project at the Broad Institute of MIT and Harvard is a team of researchers, physicians, software developers, genetic counselors, and study coordinators who believe that the latest advances in genomic sequencing are changing medicine and should be more broadly available to families with rare and undiagnosed conditions.

OurStory.Title: Our Story
OurStory.Paragraph1: The Rare Genomes Project was developed to provide access to genomic research to patients across the United States who are living with undiagnosed, suspected genetic conditions, and to engage with them as partners in the research process.
OurStory.Paragraph2: Improving the understanding of rare genetic conditions requires combining genomic research with the experiences of patients and families, and sharing this data with the research community. We hope to turn genomic data into clinically meaningful answers for families participating in the project as we advance scientific understanding of rare genetic disorders.

BroadInstitute.Title: Broad Institute
BroadInstitute.Paragraph: The Broad Institute of MIT and Harvard is a non-profit academic research institution in Cambridge, Massachusetts and is focused on using genomic data to better understand human health and disease. The Broad Institute conducts genomic sequencing and research for many projects, and has sequenced over 200,000 human genomes and 500,000 human exomes to date. One of the projects, led by Drs. Heidi Rehm and Daniel MacArthur in collaboration with other researchers, has led to the diagnosis of over 2,000 families with rare disease through genomic sequencing. In 2017, Drs. Rehm and MacArthur created the Rare Genomes Project to bring these resources directly to families.

Members.name: Heidi Rehm
Members.bio: Heidi is principal investigator of the Rare Genomes Project and the co-director for the Broad Institute Center for Mendelian Genomics. She is also the chief genomics officer of the Department of Medicine at Massachusetts General Hospital and a professor at Harvard Medical School. She built the Laboratory for Molecular Medicine at Partners HealthCare Personalized Medicine and directed it until 2018. She is a strong advocate and pioneer of open science and data sharing through leadership roles in the Clinical Genome (ClinGen) Resource and the Global Alliance for Genomics and Health.

Members.name: Anne O’Donnell-Luria
Members.bio: Anne is the medical director of the Rare Genomes Project and the co-director for the Broad Institute Center for Mendelian Genomics. She obtained her MD/PhD from Columbia University and is a board-certified clinical genetics and metabolism physician and pediatrician who sees patients at Boston Children's Hospital. She is an  assistant professor at Harvard Medical School.

Members.name: Melanie O’Leary
Members.bio: Melanie is the operations lead for the Rare Genomes Project and a principal clinical genomics specialist at the Broad Institute. She oversees the operational aspects of the project. She is a licensed, board-certified genetic counselor who has worked in a variety of clinical, research, and clinical laboratory settings.

Members.name: Brian Mangilog
Members.bio: Brian is a clinical project coordinator for the Rare Genomes Project, focusing on family engagement with the study and outreach to the rare disease community. He has a background in neurobiology and patient advocacy.

Members.name: Jillian Serrano
Members.bio: Jillian is a clinical project coordinator for the Rare Genomes Project, focusing on consenting families to the study and facilitating sample and medical record collection. She studied biology as an undergraduate and has experience in patient care and advocacy and an interest in the project's expansion to reach the Spanish speaking population.

Members.name: Grace VanNoy
Members.bio: Grace is a clinical project manager for the Rare Genomes Project. She is a licensed, board-certified genetic counselor with a background in pediatric rare disease, gene discovery, and genomic sequencing.

Members.name: Carsten Bönnemann
Members.bio: Carsten is a neuromuscular physician and senior investigator and chief of the neuromuscular and neurogenetic disorders of childhood section of the National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke (NINDS). His work aims to identify the genetic and cellular mechanisms of early onset muscle diseases, such as the congenital muscular dystrophies, congenital myopathies, and reducing body myopathy.

Members.name: Monkol Lek
Members.bio: Monkol is a co-investigator of the limb-girdle muscular dystrophy branch of the Rare Genomes Project and an assistant professor of genetics at Yale School of Medicine with affiliation at the Broad Institute. His group focuses on the development of computational methods for the analysis of genomic data from families with rare disease, particularly those with limb-girdle muscular dystrophy.

Members.name: Eric Liao
Members.bio: Eric is a plastic and reconstructive surgeon at Massachusetts General Hospital and co-investigator of the craniofacial branch of the Rare Genomes Project. He is an assistant professor of surgery at Harvard Medical School, the director of the Cleft and Craniofacial Center at Massachusetts General Hospital, and the principal investigator at the Center for Regenerative Medicine at the Harvard Stem Cell Institute.

Members.name: Daniel MacArthur
Members.bio: Daniel was the founding principal investigator of the Rare Genomes Project and also served as the co-director for the Broad Institute Center for Mendelian Genomics from 2016-2019. In 2020, he relocated to Sydney, Australia, where he now serves as the Director of the Centre for Population Genomics, jointly based at the Garvan Institute of Medical Research and the Murdoch Children's Research Institute. He is a strong advocate for and pioneer of open science and data sharing. He led the creation and release of the Exome Aggregation Consortium (ExAC) and Genome Aggregation Database (gnomAD).

Members.name: Larry Babb
Members.bio: Larry is a software engineer interested in advancing the use of genetics in both research and clinical care by developing infrastructure for capturing and sharing genetic knowledge using FAIR principles. He manages two software development teams at the Broad Institute, ClinGen and Seqr, and participates in the data sharing standards organizations of GA4GH and HL7. He has worked on both academic and commercial systems for delivering clinical genetics results and knowledge for over 16 years.

Members.name: Steve Jahl
Members.bio: Steve is a Site Reliability Engineer working on the stability and performance of our web-based research platforms. Before joining the Broad Institute, he worked as a software engineer and systems administrator in research computing groups at MIT CSAIL and Harvard Medical School.

Members.name: Hana Snow
Members.bio: Hana is a software engineer working on building tools to facilitate rare disease research. She is the lead developer for our rare disease analysis platform, seqr.

Members.name: Shifa Zhang
Members.bio: Shifa is a computational scientist and software engineer working on tools for managing and interpreting DNA sequencing data. Prior to joining the Broad Institute, Shifa developed a secure biomedical data analytics and sharing platform at Secure AI Labs.

Members.name: Christina Austin-Tse
Members.bio: Chrissy is the analysis lead for the Rare Genomes Project, an assistant laboratory director at the Mass General Brigham Laboratory for Molecular Medicine, a Molecular Geneticist at the Massachusetts General Hospital Center for Genomic Medicine, and an Instructor in Pathology at Harvard Medical School. She is a board-certified clinical molecular geneticist who specializes in the interpretation of genomic sequencing data.

Members.name: Stephanie DiTroia
Members.bio: Stephanie is a genomic variant analyst working to identify causal candidate genes and variants in rare disease exomes and genomes. Prior to joining the Broad Institute, she studied epigenetics in fetal development at the University of California, San Francisco and worked in genomic research at the HudsonAlpha Institute for Biotechnology.

Members.name: Vijay Ganesh
Members.bio: Vijay is a clinical genomic analyst and postdoctoral fellow interested in understanding the genetic architecture of adult-onset Mendelian muscle diseases, and incorporating tools such as RNA sequencing to improve the rate of diagnostic in these conditions. He is a board-certified neurologist at Brigham and Women's Hospital where he sees patients with neuromuscular disorders.

Members.name: Gabrielle Lemire
Members.bio: Gabrielle is a Clinical Genomic Variant Analyst who performs exome and genome analyses for families with rare disease. She is a board-certified Canadian medical geneticist who previously worked with the Care4Rare research program and is now pursuing a postdoctoral fellowship at the Broad Institute.

Members.name: Emily O’Heir
Members.bio: Emily is a genomic variant analyst conducting exome and genome analyses for families with rare diseases. She has a degree in diagnostic genetic sciences and previously worked in clinical cytogenetics and genomics laboratories.

Members.name: Ikeoluwa Osei-Owusu
Members.bio: Ikeoluwa is a genomic analyst assessing the disease consequence of genomic variation in families with rare disease through analysis of their exomes and/or genomes. Studying autistic children with self-injurious behavior, she received her doctoral degree in human genetics from Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine.

Members.name: Lynn Pais
Members.bio: Lynn is a senior clinical genomic analyst working to improve genetic diagnoses for families with rare genetic conditions. She is trained in genetic counseling and has over eight years of experience in clinical genetics and research settings.

Members.name: Ellie Seaby
Members.bio: Ellie is a clinical research fellow undertaking a PhD in genomic medicine at the University of Southampton in collaboration with the Broad Institute and Imperial College London. Her research focuses on the discovery of novel disease genes and improving clinical outcomes.

Members.name: Monica Wojcik
Members.bio: Monica is a clinical genomic analyst and a board-certified faculty neonatologist and geneticist at Boston Children’s Hospital. She is interested in gene discovery and improving genetic diagnosis, especially in neonatal and pediatric populations. She has a medical degree from Harvard Medical School.

Members.name: Samantha Baxter
Members.position: Associate Director, Genetic and Genomic Data Sharing
Members.bio: Sam is a licensed, board-certified genetic counselor and associate director of genetic and genomic data sharing in the Translational Genomics Group at the Broad Institute. This role includes managing the operations for gnomAD, overseeing all of the data sharing activities for the Broad’s Center for Mendelian Genomics, and leading a team of variant curators. As part of her ongoing research, she uses various curation processes to estimate the prevalence of rare disease in the global population.

Members.name: Kayla Delano
Members.bio: Kayla is a Project Coordinator for the Center for Mendelian Genomics and Rare Genomes Project. This is her second role at the Broad Institute; prior to this she was working as a research associate in the Infectious Disease and Microbiome program.

Members.name: Stacey Hall
Members.bio: Stacey is a project coordinator for the Center for Mendelian Genomics and the Rare Genomes Project. She has a masters in public health and prior to working at the Broad she worked in clinical trials research.

Members.name: Stacy-Ann Mano
Members.bio: Stacy is a senior project manager for the Center for Mendelian Genomics and the Rare Genomes Project. Prior to the Broad Institute, Stacy worked in project coordination and management at both research and clinical institutions.

Members.name: Moriel Singer-Berk
Members.bio: Moriel is a genomic variant curator working to assess the pathogenicity of variants for both clinical and research purposes. Prior to joining the Broad Institute, she received her Master's degree in Animal Biology with a focus in equine genetics at the University of California - Davis.

Members.name: Katherine Chao
Members.bio: Katherine is an associate computational biologist working on developing computational methods to aid rare disease diagnosis. She also performs exome copy number variant (CNV) calling and conducts exome and genome analyses for the Broad Center for Mendelian Genomics. Before joining the Broad Institute, she worked in the Undiagnosed Diseases program at the National Institutes of Health.

Members.name: Julia Goodrich
Members.bio: Julia is a computational biologist developing methods for the analysis of large-scale genomic datasets including the Genome Aggregation Database (gnomAD) and UK Biobank. She was previously a postdoctoral fellow in the MacArthur lab researching incomplete penetrance in monogenic metabolic conditions.

Members.name: Kristen Larrichia
Members.bio: Kristen is an associate computational biologist who works on methods to identify variants in the mitochondrial genome with the goal of improving rare disease diagnosis.

Members.name: William Phu
Members.bio: William is an associate computational biologist investigating unannotated genes and their role in rare diseases. He also contributes to the Genome Aggregation Database (gnomAD) project.

Members.name: Ben Weisburd
Members.bio: Ben is a computational scientist working on methods and tools for interpreting DNA sequencing data in the context of severe Mendelian diseases with a focus on short tandem repeats and RNA-seq.

Members.name: Michael Wilson
Members.bio: Mike is an associate computational biologist working on the preliminary analyses of exomes and genomes to identify causal candidate genes and variants. He processes and quality checks the data that is generated for analysis.

AboutUsPage.ThankYou: We thank our friends at the Broad Institute's Data Donation Platform for their critical design, engineering, and technical work on this project. Raregenomes.org is powered by the DDP's direct-to-patient study recruitment software.
AboutUsPage.Outro: Many of the patient and family portraits on our website were photographed by Season Atwater, founder of Aware of Angels. Thank you, Season, for being an amazing advocate for the rare disease community, and thank you to all of the families who so kindly shared their photos with us.

Intro.Text1: Browse through these FAQs to find answers to commonly raised questions. We also encourage you to read through the other pages of this website. If your question is not answered, please reach out to us by email at

Questions.question: What is the goal of The Rare Genomes Project?
answers: The goal of the Rare Genomes Project is to discover the genes underlying previously undiagnosed rare, genetic conditions by providing access to genomic sequencing to families affected by rare disease.

Questions.question: What does "undiagnosed" mean?
answers: For our project, we use this term to mean “genetically undiagnosed.” Genetically undiagnosed patients do not have a genetic change(s) identified that explains their symptoms. These patients may or may not have a clinical diagnosis, which is based on symptoms and other types of medical test results.

For example, individuals are most often diagnosed with cystic fibrosis based on physical symptoms and a sweat test. This is a clinical diagnosis. Having genetic testing that identifies two variants in the CFTR gene that cause cystic fibrosis is a genetic diagnosis.

Questions.question: Who is conducting the research?
answers: The Rare Genomes Project was launched by researchers Daniel MacArthur, PhD and Heidi Rehm, PhD at the Broad Institute of MIT and Harvard. We are also working in collaboration with Monkol Lek, PhD from Yale University, Eric Liao, MD from Massachusetts General Hospital, and the Lab for Molecular Medicine at Partners HealthCare Center for Personalized Medicine.
Our team is made up of researchers, physicians, software developers, genetic counselors, and study coordinators. Learn more about us here.

Questions.question: Do I have to travel to the Rare Genomes Project office in Massachusetts to participate?
answers: No. Participation is entirely remote.

Questions.question: Are there any costs to participate?
answers: There are no costs to you to participate in this study. Everything you need to participate, including the cost of sample collection, genomic sequencing, and clinical confirmation genetic testing, will be covered by us.

Questions.question: Will I receive medical care and/or treatment from the Rare Genomes Project?
answers: No. Medical care and treatment will not be provided as part of this research study.

Questions.question: What role does my medical provider play in this study?
answers: While we do not require involvement in the application process, a family's clinician can help individuals identify pertinent medical records and is also critical in partnering with us to clinically confirm and return results to families.

Questions.question: What type of sample will I be asked for?
answers: We request one small tube of blood. In rare cases, we have worked with families to explore alternative sample types.

Questions.question: What type of genetic testing is performed by the Rare Genomes Project?
answers: The Rare Genomes Project performs whole genome sequencing (WGS). WGS is a different test than whole exome sequencing (WES), which is a more focused test that is more commonly covered by insurance companies. Sometimes, we may perform additional tests including RNA sequencing. To learn more about WGS and other types of genetic testing, we recommend reading through the U.S. National Library of Medicine's MedlinePlus website.

Questions.question: I have already had whole genome sequencing. Will the Rare Genomes Project accept my external data for reanalysis?
answers: On a case-by-case basis. If you have had prior genomic sequencing, fill out an application to our study and indicate that you have prior sequencing data available. If your application is accepted, we will reach out to you and discuss the next steps. Due to the resources involved in obtaining and incorporating data from other sources, it is sometimes more time and cost effective for us to sequence your genome again.

Questions.question: Who should apply to participate?
answers: Patients and families with rare, suspected genetic disease. To see if the Rare Genomes Project might be appropriate for your family, visit our Eligibility Criteria page for more detailed information.

Questions.question: Can I apply if I live outside the United States?
answers: We currently are only able to enroll individuals that live in the United States.

Questions.question: Who in my family should participate?
answers: The nature of this project requires that the person in your family with the undiagnosed genetic condition participate. Participation by additional family members, especially both biological parents and any additional affected family members, improves our chances of finding the genetic cause of the rare, undiagnosed condition, but participation by others is not a requirement. Studies have shown that analysis of parents along with affected children increases the likelihood of diagnosis from 22% to 31% (Lee et al. 2014).

Questions.question: Can I still apply to the Rare Genomes Project in cases of adoption or if one biological parent is unavailable?
answers: Yes. We accept individuals regardless of the availability of other family members to participate. In cases where one biological parent is unavailable, we may ask about the availability of their other relatives.

Questions.question: If I complete an application, will I automatically be able to participate?
answers: No. Our clinical team reviews each application to determine whether the individual or family is a good fit for this study. In some cases, we may need to review your medical records in order to make a determination. To learn more, visit our Eligibility Criteria page.

Questions.question: Why was my application to the Rare Genomes Project not accepted?
answers: There are many reasons an application may not be accepted. Some reasons include: the condition is not likely to be caused by a change in a single gene, the approach taken by our study is not likely to diagnose the condition in question, or we believe a genetic diagnosis has already been identified. You can read more about our eligibility criteria here.

Questions.question: How and where do I get my blood drawn?
answers: We will mail you a pre-paid specimen collection kit for you to have your blood drawn at a location of your choosing. We have partnered with Quest Diagnostics, a company with thousands of blood draw locations across the United States and Puerto Rico, who will draw blood for the study and bill us directly. Alternatively, you can have your blood drawn by a local provider. If you are billed for this, send us a receipt for reimbursement.
Regardless of where you have blood drawn, please confirm with the technician that they have labeled both the blood tube and the paperwork with your legal name and date of birth.

Questions.question: What happens after I return my blood kit?
answers: After your kit is sent back to us, we will extract DNA from the blood sample and prepare it for DNA sequencing or targeted testing.

Questions.question: Who in my family will get their genome sequenced?
answers: It depends. Typically, we perform genome sequencing on the affected individual(s) in the family and their biological parents, when possible. We typically only perform targeted testing for specific variants of interest in unaffected family members.

Questions.question: What medical records are needed?
answers: We require medical records from the affected family member(s). For more information about the types of records that are needed, please see our Guide to Sharing Health Information.

Questions.question: What else might I be asked to share if I participate in this project?
answers: We may inquire about the availability of excess tissue from clinical procedures for additional testing. Because this study does not include a physical examination by study staff, we may also ask participants to share a photograph; this is optional.

Questions.question: Why am I being asked for photographs?
answers: We may ask for photographs of the member of the family with the undiagnosed condition. Some genetic syndromes are known to cause characteristic or subtle facial features that we consider when determining if a participant’s condition is related to a genetic variant. Photographs are considered part of the patient’s medical record and will not be shared externally without permission.

Questions.question: When should I update study staff?
answers: It is important to contact us if you change your contact information (such as phone number or address) or have new medical information you wish to add to your file (such as a new symptom, a genetic diagnosis from another source, or the development of the condition in other family members.)

Questions.question: Can I withdraw from the project?
answers: Yes, you can withdraw from the project at any time. If you do, your samples and your information will be destroyed. However, it will not be possible to destroy samples and information that have already been shared with other researchers. If you decide to withdraw your permission, you should contact us in writing at raregenomes@broadinstitute.org.

Questions.question: Will I receive results?
answers: Our goal is to find the genetic explanation for the undiagnosed condition in each family who enrolls, but we cannot guarantee that we will have a result for each family. If we find a genetic variant(s) that may explain the genetic condition in the family member with the condition, we work with them to clinically confirm and return the results. We do not return results to unaffected family members.

Questions.question: Will I receive results unrelated to the rare condition for which I applied?
answers: We do not actively search for genetic results unrelated to the rare condition in the family. However, if we find a genetic variant that causes a condition with treatment implications, we will contact you to discuss the option of clinically confirming the result to have it returned.

Questions.question: How will I receive my results?
answers: You can only receive results that have been confirmed in a Clinical Laboratory Improvement Amendments (CLIA)-certified laboratory. If we find results that we believe may explain the underlying cause of the rare condition present in your family, we will contact you and ask if you would like to have the findings clinically confirmed in a CLIA-certified laboratory. A genetic counselor on our staff will work with a doctor of your choice to order testing through the CLIA lab. The doctor who orders the clinical test will be the one who shares the results with you.

Questions.question: How will my genetic data be shared?
answers: One of the goals of this project is to improve rare disease diagnosis for participants and the rare disease community as a whole. Data sharing supports this goal by allowing researchers and clinicians around the world to access and perform research on the de-identified genetic data generated in this project. Learn more about how we share de-identified data here.

Questions.question: Can I have access to my genetic sequencing data?
answers: Unfortunately, no. Because the genomic sequencing in this study will be performed in a research laboratory (non-CLIA laboratory), federal regulations prohibit us from directly releasing your sequencing data to you. However, we are permitted to release data to other research studies at your request.

Questions.question: Can outside researchers access data generated as part of this project?
answers: Yes. If you are a researcher looking for more information, please visit our data sharing page.

Questions.question: Can outside researchers request samples from this study for use in their own research?
answers: In some cases, we may share de-identified samples with external collaborators. Please contact us to learn more.

Questions.question: How can I refer families with rare and undiagnosed genetic conditions to this project?
answers: If you know families who might benefit from participation in the Rare Genomes Project, please direct them to our website or have them contact us at raregenomes@broadinstitute.org. If you would like to share your participation with others, feel free to post the link to our website on your social media pages so that more families can learn about the project.

If you are a clinician who cares for a patient you believe could benefit from the Rare Genomes Project, encourage the family to fill out an online application on this website and have them indicate your name when asked about a referring provider.

Questions.question: Do you have informational materials for patients and families?
answers: Yes! Please contact us by phone at 617-714-7395 or by email at raregenomes@broadinstitute.org for copies of our materials.

Questions.question: Does the Rare Genomes Project work with other organizations?
answers: Yes! We are interested in working with advocacy groups who support families who may benefit from our research. We are also interested in raising awareness of groups that help individuals and families with rare diseases access support, resources, and future research or treatment opportunities. If you are involved with either type of advocacy group, please reach out to us by email at raregenomes@broadinstitute.org, or by phone at 617-714-7395.

Intro.Text1: The Rare Genomes Project offers research-based genomic sequencing to patients and families with an undiagnosed, suspected genetic disease. Each application that we receive is carefully reviewed by our team to determine if our study is likely to find the genetic cause of the condition in your family.

Text2.Part1: We welcome applications from families with all types of rare disease. Additionally, we have specialized branches of our project focusing on
Text2.Part5: which are described in more detail on their disease-specific pages.

List.Item1: Have a rare and genetically undiagnosed condition
List.Item3: Be currently under the care of a medical provider that is helping to understand the cause of the condition
List.Item4: Have access to a telephone and/or a computer

Text1.Part3: need to pay any fees associated with our study or travel to our office in Cambridge, Massachusetts. Participation is entirely remote and free-of-cost.

Text2.Part1: If one or more of these criteria do not apply to you, we encourage you to
Text2.Part3: We will contact you if requirements change and make you eligible to apply to the study.

Text.Part3: to benefit from our study approach are those that are suspected to have a single gene cause of disease and may have some of the following features:

List.Item1: An earlier-than-typical onset or severe presentation of symptoms
List.Item2: Multiple family members with the same (or similar) medical condition
List.Item3: Available, unaffected biological parents of the affected individual(s)
List.Item4: Some prior genetic testing that did not identify a diagnosis

Text.Part3: to benefit from our study approach include those with a condition that:

List.Item1: Is not likely to be caused by a change in a single gene (for example, Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, isolated heart defects, VACTERL, and autoimmune disorders)
List.Item2: Has a suspected or known environmental cause
List.Item4: Has not been diagnosed by prior whole genome sequencing

Text1.Part1: If you think your family is eligible, we encourage you to
Text1.Part2: learn more about how to apply

Text2.Part1: Please reach out to us by email at
Text2.Part3: if you have any questions or would like us to consider a special-case application.

Answer.Text1: We’re excited you’re interested in our project! Read through these steps to learn more about what participation in the Rare Genomes Project entails. If you think the Rare Genomes Project might be right for you, click
Answer.Text3: at the bottom of this page.

Items.title: Get to know our project
Items.text: The Rare Genomes Project is a research study focused on patients and families with rare and genetically undiagnosed conditions. We use genomic sequencing to search for the cause of rare disease in these families and hope to accelerate the rate of rare disease diagnosis in the process. For more information, review our eligibility criteria and read through the steps below.

Items.title: Tell us about your family
Items.text: During the application process, we will ask about the rare, suspected genetic disease in your family, limited demographic information, family history information, and the results of previous genetic and other tests. After you complete your application, our study team will review the information you submit to determine if you are a good fit for the study. If so, we will set up a video meeting or phone conference with you and your family to explain the study and make sure that all of your questions are answered. Each person in the family will receive a consent document to sign to participate.

Items.title: Share your medical history
Items.text: After signing consent documents, we will ask for copies of medical records, including genetic test results, from affected family members. You can send this information by mail or secure fax using the information provided after your consent session.

Items.title: Send us your sample
Items.text: Once enrolled, we will mail pre-paid sample collection kits directly to you and your family. You can take these kits to your local Quest Diagnostics facility, or to a local doctor’s office or hospital. We cover all fees associated with sample collection.

Items.title: Have your DNA sequenced
Items.text: When your sample arrives at our lab, we will extract DNA from the sample and perform genomic sequencing. To learn more about genomic sequencing, you can visit the U.S. National Library of Medicine's Help Me Understand Genetics page.

Items.title: Have your genomic data analyzed
Items.text: To search for the genetic cause of your condition, we will compare your genome to hundreds of thousands of other individuals without your condition as well as your family members. This allows us to identify which DNA variants in your genome are potentially related to your condition.

Items.title: Share your data
Items.text: Sharing your symptoms and genomic data with other researchers and clinicians makes finding others with similar symptoms and changes in the same genes more likely. You can learn more about the ways we share data and our privacy policy here.

Items.title: Receive clinically significant results
Items.text: If we find results that we believe may explain the cause of your rare condition, we will contact you and ask if you would like to have the findings confirmed with our clinical laboratory partner, the Laboratory for Molecular Medicine (LMM) in Cambridge, MA. If you do, we will work with you and your doctor to return the results to you.

Start.Text: If this project sounds like it could benefit you or a loved one, we encourage you to fill out an online application here:

AnyQuestions.Question: Still have questions?
AnyQuestions.Text1: If you do not see your question

PrivacyAndYourDataPage.Title: Privacy and Your Data
PrivacyAndYourDataPage.Intro: Genomic sequencing is just the first step in understanding rare diseases- sharing your symptoms and genomic data with other researchers and clinicians makes finding others with similar symptoms and changes in the same genes more likely.

DataSharing.Title: What is Data Sharing?
DataSharing.Text1: Data sharing means that sequencing and limited clinical data from this project will be shared with others outside our project. Those who would like to access the data we produce in the Rare Genomes Project are often other scientists who are interested in learning more about the genetics of a specific disease or condition. Because any given rare disease affects so few people, data sharing enables scientists worldwide to connect with one another and accelerate the speed of new discoveries in genetic disease.
DataSharing.Text2: We will utilize multiple platforms to share your sequencing data and key symptoms of the rare genetic disease in your family. The information that we share is de-identified, meaning that your name, date of birth, contact information, or other personal identifiers are never shared.

Paragraph1.Text1: We share variant information when we are suspicious that a specific variant may cause a rare disease. For this type of variant, we share information through an online tool called
Paragraph1.Text3: which helps researchers and clinicians connect with one another. These connections can lead to collaborations that help establish evidence that variants and genes are related to rare diseases.

Paragraph2.Text1: We also share variant information when we have confirmed that a variant causes a rare disease. For these variants, we share information through an online, public database called
Paragraph2.Text3: ClinVar serves as a reference that clinicians and scientists can use to know which genetic changes have been found in patients and associated with genetic diseases.

GenomicInformation.Title: How We Share Full Genomic Information
GenomicInformation.Text1: We share full genomic sequencing data and summarized medical information through two platforms to help increase the pace of scientific discovery. For example, data is stored at the Broad Institute and accessible after approval by its Data Use Oversight System (DUOS).
GenomicInformation.Text2: We also share data through a similar, federally-funded genomic database called AnVIL. Interested researchers must apply and be granted access to the data in these platforms.

Privacy.Title: Privacy
Privacy.Text: Data sharing is important to advancing the understanding of rare genetic disease, and we have many safeguards in place to ensure that the data we collect as part of our project is securely stored and shared responsibly. Below are some frequently asked questions about privacy and data usage in the Rare Genomes Project.

Stored.Question: How is my data stored?
Stored.Answer: We store genetic and electronic data (such as electronic medical records) on secure, encrypted systems belonging to the Broad Institute and Partners HealthCare, the hospital organization responsible for this project. Your data is labeled with a randomized, numerical study ID available only to study staff. Physical data (such as paper medical records) are stored in a secure, locked cabinet in the study staff office.

Shared.Question: Will my name or personal information be shared with other researchers and clinicians?
Shared.Answer: Never. The genetic data that we generate in the project is de-identified, meaning that it does not contain personally identifiable information such as your name or date of birth.

Profit.Question: Will the Rare Genomes Project profit off of my data?
Profit.Answer: Never. The Rare Genomes Project is a non-profit research study and will not sell your genomic data.

Ending.Text1: We discuss data sharing during the consent call if you are accepted into the project and will make sure you understand how your data will be used. If you have questions or concerns about privacy that are not answered above, please contact us by email at

ForYourPhysicianPage.Title: For your Physician
ForYourPhysicianPage.Intro: The Rare Genomes Project is a research study at The Broad Institute of MIT and Harvard, a non-profit academic research institution focused on using genomic data to better understand human health and disease. Our team, led by investigator Heidi Rehm, has a specific focus on understanding the genetic basis of very rare and undiagnosed conditions. Our mission is to partner directly with patients, families, advocates, and clinicians and to increase patients’ access to genomic research.

HowItWorks.Title: How it works
Paragraphs: The Rare Genomes Project provides undiagnosed families with the opportunity to participate in a genomic research study, regardless of where in the United States they live. To ensure that participation is made broadly available to any eligible family, all study procedures can be completed from, or nearby, the patient’s home.

Interested participants and families can visit www.raregenomes.org to learn more about the project. By clicking “Start an Application,” they can apply to participate. Our clinical team will review each application and eligible families will be invited to enroll.

We will send a collection kit to enrolled families who can choose to have blood drawn at a Quest Diagnostics Patient Service Center (www.questdiagnostics.com/appointment) or at another phlebotomy location of their choice. In some cases, we may be able to request DNA from prior genetic testing. The sample collection kits will be mailed back to our lab, where DNA extraction and genomic sequencing will be performed.

Our team will analyze genomic data alongside each family’s clinical information with the goal of identifying the genetic basis of the condition present in the family. If we are able to identify the cause of disease, we will re-contact the family and pursue clinical confirmation in partnership with a local provider of their choosing. The clinical confirmation report will be issued to the local ordering provider.

This project is dedicated to rapid and open data sharing. De-identified genetic and clinical data generated in this project will be shared broadly with the wider rare and undiagnosed community, as well as other clinicians and researchers, through controlled-access genomic databases, as well as the Matchmaker Exchange, and Clinvar.

Lists.Title: Patients and families with a rare and genetically undiagnosed condition who:
Items: Are currently under the care of a doctor that is helping to understand the cause of the patient’s condition

Lists.Title: At this time, we are unable to include patients and families that:
Items: Have a suspected or known environmentally caused condition
Have any condition not likely to be monogenic
Have a genetic diagnosis that fully explains the patient’s condition.

Help.Title: How to refer a family
Help.Text: If you currently provide care for families that you think would be a good fit for participation in this project, please refer them to our website www.raregenomes.org. We also partner directly with clinicians, hospitals, and institutions to increase awareness about the project. If you would like us to provide brochures and informational materials for patients that visit your clinic, please contact us.

Role.Title: Your role in the project
Role.Text1: We are interested in partnering with clinical providers of participants to facilitate the return of medically-relevant, clinically-confirmed results discovered in this project.
Role.Text2: Other ways that you could be involved:
Role.Item1: Aggregating and summarizing the family’s medical records and clinical information
Role.Item2: Addressing follow-up questions that arise during the family’s involvement in the project

ForYourPhysicianPage.ThankYou: Thank you for your support. We look forward to learning with you!

DataAccessPage.Title: Data Sharing
DataAccessPage.Text: The Rare Genomes Project is based at the Broad Institute of MIT and Harvard, a non-profit research institution in Cambridge, Massachusetts. The aim of the project is to use genomic sequencing of affected individuals and their family members to identify the genetic causes of rare disease. Our team, led by principal investigator Heidi Rehm, is committed to open science and rapid data sharing, with the hope of improving the rate of rare disease diagnosis through collaborations with other researchers worldwide. De-identified data generated by the project will be shared on platforms including:

MatchmakerExchange.Title: Matchmaker Exchange
MatchmakerExchange.Text: Matchmaker Exchange (MME) allows researchers, laboratories, and clinicians to submit anonymized genotype and phenotype information to a federated platform of international stakeholders in the hopes of “matching” with others who submitted a case with overlapping clinical symptoms or genetic variants. The Rare Genomes Project enters variants of interest into MME on an ongoing basis. To access MME’s resources, individuals must submit their own cases or datasets to begin matching. To learn more about how to get started with MME’s services, visit their website.

ClinVar.Title: ClinVar
ClinVar.Text: ClinVar is a publicly accessible NCBI database that collects and displays information about genetic variants and their relationship to human disease. Clinical laboratories and researchers submit variant information along with the interpretation of its pathogenicity. Reportable variants identified through the project are most often submitted to ClinVar by our clinical partner, the Laboratory for Molecular Medicine. Direct submissions by the Rare Genomes Project are listed under the entry for the Broad Institute Rare Disease Group.

DUOS.Title: DUOS
DUOS.Text: The Broad Institute developed the Data Use Oversight System (DUOS) to streamline the sharing of de-identified clinical and genomic sequencing data with the research community. To access data generated by the Rare Genomes Project, researchers may visit the DUOS website, apply for access, and describe how they will use the data for their research study. This request will then be reviewed by the DUOS data access committee, who must review and approve the request before access to the data is granted. Approved researchers will gain access to genomic sequencing data and clinical information from RGP families, but with all personally identifiable information removed. The Rare Genomes Project submits data to DUOS on an ongoing basis under dataset name ‘RGP_Rehm_RareDisease_WGS’ and ID number DUOS_000008. The Rare Genomes Project does not process applications to DUOS. For more information about DUOS or to address questions about your application, please visit DUOS’s support page.

AnVIL.Title: AnVIL
AnVIL.Text1: The NHGRI Genomic Data Science Analysis, Visualization, and Informatics Lab-Space (AnVIL) is a federally-funded resource for the genomic scientific community that leverages a cloud-based infrastructure for genomic data access, sharing, and computing. AnVIL provides a collaborative environment with user interfaces for datasets and analysis workflows.
AnVIL.Text2: To access data generated by the Rare Genomes Project, researchers apply for access. Approved researchers will gain access to genomic sequencing data and clinical information from RGP families, but with all personally identifiable information removed. The Rare Genomes Project submits data to AnVIL on an ongoing basis under Broad Institute Center for Mendelian Genomics in the subset workspace AnVIL_CMG_Broad_Rare_RGP_WGS, with ID number phs001272.v2.p1. The Rare Genomes Project does not process applications to AnVIL. For more information about AnVIL or to address questions about your application, please visit https://anvilproject.org/.

Questions.Text1: If you have further questions, please contact us by email at

LGMDPage.Title: The limb-girdle muscular dystrophy (LGMD) branch of the Rare Genomes Project is a partnership with the Muscular Dystrophy Association and the Jain Foundation dedicated to diagnosis and gene discovery through whole genome sequencing for individuals and families with LGMD.
LGMDPage.ImageAlt: If you or a loved one has a rare and genetically undiagnosed condition, join a patient-driven research study to discover the genes underlying your family's rare disease.

Background.Title: Background
Background.Text: The limb-girdle muscular dystrophies are a group of muscle diseases characterized by weakness and wasting of the muscles in the hips, legs, shoulders, and/or other proximal muscles. There are currently over 30 known forms of LGMD, with a diverse range of clinical signs and symptoms, that collectively are estimated to affect as many as 1 in 15,000 individuals.

Genetics.Title: Genetics and LGMD
Genetics.Text: Multiple studies estimate that roughly half of those undergoing genetic testing do not have a causative DNA variant in any of the known LGMD-causing genes. This project enables individuals who have had negative or incomplete results from prior genetic testing to participate in a study using whole-genome sequencing (WGS) to search for additional causes of LGMD.

Right.Title: Is This Study Right For Me?
Right.Text: Our efforts will focus on individuals and families who:
Items: Have a clinical diagnosis of LGMD*
Have had prior genetic testing that was negative or did not provide a full genetic explanation*
Are currently under the care of a neurologist, medical geneticist, or relevant subspecialist

Ending.Text1: *If you are unsure whether you have a clinical diagnosis of LGMD or you have not had prior genetic testing for your LGMD, you may still be eligible to participate and are encouraged to apply by

One.Title: Tell us your story
One.Text3: to see a broad overview of the study and learn how you can start an application. The information will be reviewed by our study team, and eligible families will be invited to participate. We will arrange a time to have a detailed discussion about the study and send a consent form.

Two.Title: Submit a sample
Two.Text: Once enrolled, we’ll mail a pre-paid sample collection kit directly to you and your family. We’ll also ask you more about medical history and ask for copies of medical records, including genetic test results.

Three.Title: Discover
Three.Text: Through DNA sequencing, we may discover the genetic cause of the LGMD in your family and will work with you and your doctors to return important results to you. We will also share de-identified data broadly with the scientific community to empower discoveries in rare and undiagnosed disease, including LGMD.

Info.Title: Information and Resources
Info.Text: Additional information and resources for individuals with LGMD are can be found here: Muscular Dystrophy Association, GeneReviews, and the U.S. National Library of Medicine Medline Plus.

Partner.Text: We thank the Muscular Dystrophy Association for their financial support of this project.

CraniofacialPage.Title: The craniofacial branch of the Rare Genomes Project is a partnership with the Cleft and Craniofacial Center at Massachusetts General Hospital and Shriners Hospitals for Children dedicated to genetic diagnosis and gene discovery for congenital craniofacial conditions.
CraniofacialPage.Text: This project enables patients with undiagnosed, suspected single gene forms of craniofacial conditions to participate in a study using whole genome sequencing to search for the genetic cause of the craniofacial condition in their family.
CraniofacialPage.ImageAlt: If you or a loved one has a rare and genetically undiagnosed condition, join a patient-driven research study to discover the genes underlying your family's rare disease.

Background.Title: Background
Background.Text: Craniofacial conditions affect the development of bones and tissues of the head and face. They can occur in isolation, with additional craniofacial conditions, or as one feature of an underlying syndrome affecting other parts of the body. For example, facial clefts can be an isolated condition, can co-occur with craniosynostosis, or can be part of a genetic syndrome such as Treacher Collins syndrome. Collectively, the many types of craniofacial conditions are estimated to affect approximately 1 in 700-1,000 newborns.

Genetics.Title: Genetics and Craniofacial Conditions
Genetics.Text: Craniofacial conditions may be caused by genetic changes, environmental factors, or a combination of the two. The likelihood of a strictly genetic cause is increased if the condition is atypically severe or rare, there are delays in development or health issues affecting additional body systems, or there are multiple affected family members. Although many single gene causes have been identified, our goal is to identify additional genes that cause craniofacial conditions.

Right.Title: Is This Study Right For Me?
Right.Text: Our initial efforts will focus on individuals and families who:

Item1.Text:
Have a craniofacial condition that is suspected to be due to a single gene.
Features suggesting a single gene cause include:

Subitems.Item1: An atypically severe presentation or a rare condition
Subitems.Item2: Involvement of both sides of the face or head (e.g. ears), or the middle structures (e.g. nose), depending on the condition
Subitems.Item3: Additional early-onset medical conditions affecting different parts of the body or delays in development
Subitems.Item4: Presence in siblings or multiple generations of family members

ListItems.Item2: Do NOT have a condition with a low suspicion of a single gene cause, such as isolated cleft lip and/or palate, isolated microtia, or hemifacial microsomia
ListItems.Item3: Are currently under the care of a medical geneticist or relevant subspecialist

One.Title: Tell us your story
One.Text3: to see a broad overview of the study and learn how you can start an application. The information will be reviewed by our study team, and eligible families will be invited to participate. We will arrange a time to have a detailed discussion about the study and send a consent form.

Two.Title: Submit a sample
Two.Text: Once enrolled, we’ll mail a pre-paid sample collection kit directly to you and your family. We’ll also ask you more about medical history and ask for copies of medical records, including genetic test results.

Three.Title: Discover
Three.Text: Through DNA sequencing, we may discover the genetic cause of the craniofacial condition in your family and will work with you and your doctors to return important results to you. We will also share de-identified data broadly with the scientific community to empower discoveries in rare and undiagnosed disease, including craniofacial conditions.

Info.Title: Information and Resources
Info.Text: Additional information and resources for individuals with isolated and syndromic craniofacial conditions can be found here: Shriners Hospitals for Children, the American Cleft Palate and Craniofacial Association, GeneReviews, and the U.S. National Library of Medicine Medline Plus.

Info.Paragraph1: Thank you for your interest in the Rare Genomes Project. This page will provide you information about the steps regarding your involvement with the study.

Paragraph2.Intro: If you have questions, browse our
Paragraph2.Closing: page or contact the study staff at 617-714-7395 (Toll-free: 855-534-4300) or raregenomes@broadinstitute.org.

ErrorPage.Title: We've encountered an error
ErrorPage.Text1: Please wait a moment and retry. If the trouble persists, please email us at

CountMeInPage.Title: Tell us your story
CountMeInPage.SectionTitle: Thank you for your interest in joining the Rare Genomes Project!
CountMeInPage.Text: To get started, please let us know if you or a loved one meets the participation requirements listed below by attesting that all of the statements listed next to the checkboxes below are true. You will then be asked to create a raregenomes.org account and complete a questionnaire to tell us about the rare condition in your family. The information will be reviewed by our study team, and eligible families will be invited to participate.

SessionExpiredPage.Text1: You were away for a while, so we logged you out as a security precaution.
SessionExpiredPage.Text2: Please log in again to return to the last page you were on.

Auth0LandingPage.Text: Please wait. You will be redirected to a destination soon...

EmailVerifiedCallbackPage.Text: Please wait. You will be redirected to a login page soon...

EmailVerificationRequiredPage.Text: Please verify your email using the link that was sent to your email address.

ThankYouPage.Title: Thank you for your interest in joining the Rare Genomes Project
ThankYouPage.Paragraph1: Unfortunately, your responses to our pre-screening questionnaire do not match the current requirements for participation in the study. The Rare Genomes Project can only accept applications from families who meet all of these conditions:
List: Have a rare and genetically undiagnosed condition
Are currently under the care of a medical provider who is helping to understand the cause of your condition
ThankYouPage.Paragraph2: Over time, we may be able to expand the project. If you join our mailing list below, we can contact you if these participation requirements change.

Form.Label: Email Address *
Form.Error: Please enter a valid Email Address

ThankYouPage.Paragraph3: If you would like your information to be deleted from our database at any time, please email us at raregenomes@broadinstitute.org.

InReview.Subject: Application
InReview.Message: Your application is being reviewed. We will contact you as soon as a decision about your application has been made. If you do not hear from our office within 6 weeks, please contact us.
InReview.More: Please be aware that we may contact you by phone or email. The emails we send you that contain personal identifiers or health information will be sent using an encryption tool called Send Secure unless you have specifically chosen otherwise. These emails can be identified by the words "Send Secure" in the subject field, will come from an email address ending in @partners.org, and will ask you to click on an attachment to create an account. If you are unsure if the email you received is from us, please contact us.

ThankYou.Subject: Application
ThankYou.Message: At any time during your involvement with the study, contact us with any questions or concerns.
ThankYou.More: Please be aware that we may contact you by phone or email. The emails we send you that contain personal identifiers or health information will be sent using an encryption tool called Send Secure unless you have specifically chosen otherwise. These emails can be identified by the words "Send Secure" in the subject field, will come from an email address ending in @partners.org, and will ask you to click on an attachment to create an account. If you are unsure if the email you received is from us, please contact us.

Accepted.Subject: Application decision
Accepted.Message: Your application has been reviewed, and you are eligible to participate.
Accepted.More: The next step is to schedule an appointment for a Consent Session. See above.

NotAccepted.Subject: Application decision
NotAccepted.Message: Your application has been reviewed, and unfortunately, you are not eligible to participate.
NotAccepted.More:
The Rare Genomes Project is a research study aimed at understanding the genetic causes of rare and undiagnosed conditions in families. Our study uses genomic approaches to find changes in a single gene that result in a medical condition. There are a number of situations where our approach is not likely to be successful. Due to this, we are not able to enroll all families who have applied. Some reasons for this include, but are not limited to, families that have:

  • Family members with very different medical conditions
  • A condition which is not likely to be caused by a change in a single gene
  • A condition where genomic sequencing is not the best test to use for diagnosis
  • Already received a genetic diagnosis

Following is a list of resources that may provide information or support for your family:

  • National Organization for Rare Disorders: An advocacy organization dedicated to improving the lives of patients and families impacted by rare disease. They provide information on diseases, genetic testing, financial assistance programs, clinical trials, and more.
  • Global Genes: A rare disease patient advocacy organization that promotes the varied needs of the rare disease community. Their mission is to build awareness, educate the global community, and provide critical connections and resources that equip advocates to become activists for their disease.
  • GenomeConnect: An online patient registry where individuals can securely share their genetic and health information with researchers, connect with others with similar genetic test results or diagnoses, learn about additional research opportunities, and receive updates about their genetic test results.
  • MyGene2: A registry where families can create their own entry and connect with other families, clinicians, and researchers interested in similar genetic findings.
  • Medline Plus: Genetics: A federally-funded resource of information about genetics and the role of genes in human disease.
  • Clinicaltrials.gov: A database of privately- and publicly-funded research studies from around the world. Visitors are able to search by disease name or symptoms as well as gene(s) of interest.

MoreInfoNeeded.Subject: Application decision
MoreInfoNeeded.Message: Your application has been reviewed, and we need more information to make a decision about your eligibility to participate.
MoreInfoNeeded.More:
We would like to review the medical records for the person in the family with rare disease. In order to review medical records, that individual must be enrolled in the study.

To proceed, the family member with the rare disease should schedule a Consent Session (see above). Only the individual with rare disease (age 7 or older) needs to attend with his/her legal guardian, if applicable. After review of medical records, our team will determine if your family is eligible to proceed with the study.

NMI.Subject: Application decision
NMI.Message: Medical records have been reviewed, and you are eligible to participate.
NMI.More:
Here are the next steps for you and your family:

  • Sample collection: We will send you a sample collection kit (see above).
  • Enroll family members: Please contact us to discuss which family members we would invite to participate. Whenever possible, we seek to enroll both biological parents, other affected family members, and up to two healthy siblings. Similar to the family member who already enrolled, these additional family members will need to have a Consent Session with one of our team members to learn more about the study before deciding about participation.

ScheduleNeeded.Subject: Consent session
ScheduleNeeded.Message: Please schedule an appointment for a Consent Session.

Scheduled.Subject: Consent session
Scheduled.Message: Your Consent Session has been scheduled.
Scheduled.More:
If you need to reschedule your appointment, please use the link in the email confirmation you received. If you need assistance, please call our office at 617-714-7395.

If other members of your family need to schedule a Consent Session, they can make an appointment here.

SignedFormRequired.Subject: Consent form
SignedFormRequired.Message: Thank you for attending the Consent Session. A signed consent form is required to move forward with the study.
SignedFormRequired.More:
You will receive an email from AdobeSign with an electronic copy of the consent form (and assent form, if applicable). If you would like to participate, please electronically sign the form(s), which will automatically be sent back to us. If you have any questions or if you have decided not to participate, please contact us.

If other members of your family need to schedule a Consent Session, they can make an appointment here.

SignedFormReceived.Subject: Consent form
SignedFormReceived.Message: A signed consent form has been received.
SignedFormReceived.More:
See items above for your next steps.

If other members of your family need to schedule a consent session, they can make an appointment here.

Decline.Subject: Consent form
Decline.Message: You have decided not to participate in this study.
Decline.More: If you should change your mind at a later date, please call us.

NoRecords.Subject: Medical records
NoRecords.Message: Copies of medical records are needed.
NoRecords.More:
Typically, the most important records for us to receive are:

  • specialist clinic notes (e.g. neurologist, cardiologist, nephrologist), especially genetics
  • genetic test reports, if any
  • pathology reports, if any
  • MRI or CT scan reports, if any

Please see our “Guide for Sharing Your Family’s Health Information” for more information.

Records can be sent to us by:

  • Fax: 617-800-1909
  • Mail: Rare Genomes Project, Broad Institute, Attn: Dr. Heidi Rehm, 415 Main Street, Cambridge MA 02142
  • Email: Please let us know if you would like to email records, and we can set up a secure email connection to ensure additional protection of your medical information.

If you encounter any costs associated with sending the medical records, please send us a receipt so that we can reimburse you.

Partial.Subject: Medical records
Partial.Message: We have received some of the medical records needed.
Partial.More:
We are awaiting additional records. Typically, the most important records for us to receive are:

  • specialist clinic notes (e.g. neurologist, cardiologist, nephrologist), especially genetics
  • genetic test reports, if any
  • pathology reports, if any
  • MRI or CT scan reports, if any

Please see our “Guide for Sharing Your Family’s Health Information” for more information.

Records can be sent to us by:

  • Fax: 617-800-1909
  • Mail: Rare Genomes Project, Broad Institute, Attn: Dr. Heidi Rehm, 415 Main Street, Cambridge MA 02142
  • Email: Please let us know if you would like to email records, and we can set up a secure email connection to ensure additional protection of your medical information.

If you encounter any costs associated with sending the medical records, please send us a receipt so that we can reimburse you.

Received.Subject: Medical records
Received.Message: We have received your records. Thank you!

NA.Subject: Medical records
NA.Message: We do not need medical records at this time.

Enrolled.Subject: Survey
Enrolled.Message: An email with a link to an optional survey will be sent to you 7 days after you signed the consent form.
Enrolled.More:
The survey asks questions about your experience with the rare disease present in you or your child. We are using these questions to research the impact of having a rare disease and the reasons for participating in genomic research.

If you do not receive an email with a survey link, please contact our office by phone or email.

Complete.Subject: Survey
Complete.Message: Your survey response has been received. Thank you!

Enrolled.Subject: Sample
Enrolled.Message: A sample collection kit will be sent to you in approximately 2 weeks.
Enrolled.More: We will update you when it has been sent.

Sent.Subject: Sample
Sent.Message: A sample collection kit has been sent to you.
Sent.More:
You can have your blood drawn at a location of your choosing. Regardless of where you choose have your blood drawn, please confirm with the technician that they have labeled both the blood tube and the paperwork in the box with your legal name and date of birth:

If you go to Quest Diagnostics, we recommend that you make an appointment online to ensure you are seen promptly. They require that the blood be drawn Monday-Friday before 2 PM to ensure they can send it back to us the same day. The required Quest paperwork is in the box. They will take care of shipping the sample to us and will bill us directly for the service.

If you go to your doctor's office or hospital’s lab, we recommend you call the location before you go to ensure they are willing to draw the sample. The pre-paid FedEx shipping materials inside the box can be used to send the sample back to us. If there is a charge for the blood draw, send us a copy of the bill so we can reimburse you. Please call our office if we can be of assistance.

Received.Subject: Sample
Received.Message: Your sample has been received. Thank you!

Withdraw.Subject: Withdraw
Withdraw.Message: You have decided to withdraw from the study.
Withdraw.More: Your sample, medical records and/or data will be destroyed. We are unable to destroy samples and information that have already been shared with other researchers.

FamilyStepsComplete.Subject: Sequencing and Analysis
FamilyStepsComplete.Message: Your study activities are now complete.
FamilyStepsComplete.More: Your participation will help us in our search for a genetic explanation for the undiagnosed condition in your family member. Thank you for taking part in this study!

ProbandStepsComplete.Subject: Sequencing and Analysis
ProbandStepsComplete.Message: We have received your sample and are processing it for sequencing.
ProbandStepsComplete.More:
It typically takes 4-6 months before we have data to analyze. Then, our team of analysts will begin look for connections between genetic changes present and your symptoms. If we identify a genetic change that we believe may be related to your medical condition, we will contact you to discuss confirmation testing in a clinical laboratory.

Our goal is to find the genetic explanation for the undiagnosed condition in each family who enrolls, but we cannot guarantee that there will be a result for each family. If we do not initially find a result, we will keep your family enrolled and re-analyze the data again at a later date since the scientific understanding of human disease as well as our tools for analyzing genetic data are constantly improving.

Because medical conditions can change over time, please contact our office if new symptoms appear or if you receive a diagnosis through an alternate means.

As always, please contact us if you have questions about your family’s progress in the study. Thank you for participating in the Rare Genomes Project!

ProbandNeg.Subject: Sequencing and Analysis
ProbandNeg.Message: We have not identified a result to date.
ProbandNeg.More:
Analysis of your DNA and health information has not revealed a genetic variant that we think explains your condition.

Our goal is to find the genetic explanation for the undiagnosed condition in each family who enrolls, but we cannot guarantee that there will be a result for each family. We will keep your family enrolled and re-analyze the data again at a later date since the scientific understanding of human disease as well as our tools for analyzing genetic data are constantly improving.

Because medical conditions can change over time, please contact our office if new symptoms appear or if you receive a diagnosis through an alternate means.

As always, please contact us if you have questions about your family’s progress in the study.

JoinMailingList.Title: Thank you for your interest in joining the Rare Genomes Project!
JoinMailingList.Text:
Unfortunately, your responses to our pre-screening questionnaire do not match the current requirements for participation in the study. The Rare Genomes Project can only accept applications from families who meet all of these conditions:

  • Understand English
  • Live in the United States
  • Have a rare and undiagnosed genetic condition
  • Are currently under the care of a doctor helping to figure out the cause of the patient’s condition

Over time, we may be able to expand the project. We hope you will join our mailing list. If you do, we will contact you if participation requirements change, making you eligible to apply to the study.
